This review is from a non‚ÄìHarry Potter fan who ended up loving the Harry Potter world!
I had never watched any of the Harry Potter movies before playing this game, nor did I manage to finish the Harry Potter novel that one of my teachers had gifted me.
Looking at the reviews and some interesting shorts on YouTube, I bought this game thinking I might abandon it just like many other games in my library, but to my surprise I got interested in the Harry Potter world right from the very start of the game, where I had to answer questions and get into one of the Houses, i also ended up watching all the movies just after completing the first few quests.

The gameplay is fun and very repetitive at the same time, and might get boring unless you encounter new enemies or unlock new spells.
The gear and equipment system is one of the most useless features in the game that should have never been there.
The world is fantastic and dynamic, with many interesting things scattered all around.
The art style is amazing ‚Äî gives Red Dead Redemption vibes with its polished graphics.
The story is not that interesting; the threat doesn't seem that big and there is nothing at stake (there is actually, but it doesn't give that feeling at all).
For me the performance was fine with DLSS and Intel‚Äôs FG, with no lags, good frametime, and 100 FPS on an RTX 3060 with Medium to High settings.

Overall, the game is pretty fun when it comes to exploring new areas on the map, trying out new spells, seeing new people and enemies, but quests become boring at times and gameplay is repetitive. Still, it is definitely worth buying and immersing yourself into the Harry Potter world.

Overall, this is a prime example of a 7/10 game. Enjoyable enough story and combat make up the core of this game, but the beautiful open world is the highlight. Everything [i]feels[/i] very "Harry Potter" - Hogwarts  is imposing and labyrinthian, and Hogsmede is whimsical and charming.

However, performance is an issue (granted, I don't have a powerful desktop), and the control during combat sometimes feels clunky - its difficult to switch between targets, and button inputs are sometimes not registered. Controller-based menu control is minimal and mostly involves navigating menus by steering a cursor with the joystick. Character animations don't always match up with what is being said, and I've missed important dialog because owl letters from other characters narrate through cutscenes. The worldbuilding alternates between being very interesting and nonsensical, and character dialog options are typically limited to "enthusiastic yes" and "demeaning no", often with no impact on gameplay.

My recommendation: turn your brain off, ignore the jank, and just enjoy being in a whimsical world where everything revolves around you.

I didn‚Äôt really buy this for myself as much as I did the kids, since I‚Äôm not really into HP, but I did play it for a while.

I was rather impressed that they managed to make an adventure game + ARPG hybrid that seemed to fit the setting perfectly. Normally I‚Äôd expect something like an HP game to just be some sort of point and click adventure game, and if not that then I‚Äôd expect it to be completely on rails, but they seemed to have managed to create a ‚Äúreal‚Äù game with character progression and a map with fast travel gates.

I mean it‚Äôs not Fallout 4, Skyrim, Legend of Zelda BOTW, but they managed to at least get some of that sort of gameplay, such as wand battles and character improvement over time.

The only thing that really bugs me personally is the overabundance of cut scenes, and the length of the cut scenes, but I guess it isn‚Äôt surprising for anything based on a movie franchise. It does make the game take up a lot of disk storage though.

I think I could sum this up as recommended for those who are actually HP fans, unsure about those who aren‚Äôt HP fans because the game is good enough that anyone who likes kind of ‚Äúfluffy‚Äù semi-RPGs with a lot of ‚Äúadventure game‚Äù stuff like puzzle-type things will probably like it. But definitely not recommended for hardcore RPG players as this is definitely not a hardcore battle-oriented RPG.

As a long-time Harry Potter fan, Hogwarts Legacy was everything I hoped for and more. The world is stunningly detailed‚ÄîI often found myself flying around just to enjoy the scenery instead of fast traveling, because exploring the landscape truly felt magical.

The combat was a major highlight. It‚Äôs incredibly fluid, and mixing different spell combinations made every fight feel dynamic and stylish. Experimenting with spell setups was some of the most fun I had in the entire game.

I also absolutely loved the Room of Requirement. Such a cool concept, with entire spaces dedicated to your magical creatures‚Äîraising them, breeding them, and caring for them. Plus the customizable areas for brewing potions and growing plants were amazing. I didn‚Äôt explore it nearly as much as I could‚Äôve, but I still made sure to decorate it and make it look good.

I fully completed the game and 100%ed all the achievements, and while the endgame gets a bit grindy, it added to the sense of progression instead of dragging it down.

Overall, Hogwarts Legacy is a beautiful, immersive, and endlessly fun experience that captures the magic of the Wizarding World better than any game before it.

I often see people criticizing this game, saying it's boring or it's not "open world" enough. We were all at that age reading Harry Potter, fantasizing about one day an owl would land on our window and take us to a magical world. Call this game boring or even "pre-made", it doesn't matter. I'd still like it even more. We don't need it to be more creative or have a more open world. What we want to go to is the little world Rowling created. Do we really think just going to class and looking at the scenery is boring? But that was all the fantasies of that child ten years ago. Back then, after reading the book, I dreamt of going to Hogwarts, catching chocolate frogs on the train at Platform 9¬æ, walking up the spiral staircase, and visiting my common room. I remember back then there was no chance to see the movie, let alone the AI-generated content like we have now. I could only look at the blurry illustrations on the pirated pages and use my meagre imagination to fantasize about that magical and mysterious world. Calling it a game was less accurate than calling it a trip down memory lane; it was more like taking me back to my childhood dreams.

In nearly every way, Hogwarts Legacy is the Harry Potter RPG I‚Äôve always wanted to play. Its open-world adventure captures all the excitement and wonder of the Wizarding World with its memorable new characters, challenging and nuanced combat, and a wonderfully executed Hogwarts student fantasy that kept me glued to my controller for dozens of hours. It‚Äôs certainly weighed down by technical issues, a lackluster main story, and some poor enemy variety, but even those couldn‚Äôt come close to breaking its enchanting spell over me.

Hogwarts Legacy is the kind of game many fans of the Wizarding World have been dreaming about for years. It finally gives you the chance to experience life as a student at Hogwarts ‚Äî exploring the castle, learning spells, brewing potions, and uncovering hidden secrets.

The strongest part of the game is definitely its atmosphere. Hogwarts feels alive: moving staircases, secret passages, cozy common rooms, and beautiful outdoor areas make exploration genuinely exciting. It‚Äôs easy to get lost in the world just by wandering around and discovering small details. The music and sound design also add a lot to the magical feeling, making the experience feel immersive and emotionally engaging.

While the main story starts off interesting, it doesn‚Äôt always reach its full potential. Some quests and activities can feel repetitive over time, and your choices don‚Äôt have as much impact on the world as you might expect from an RPG. At times, the open world looks beautiful but feels a bit empty in terms of meaningful interactions.

Overall, it is a magical and enjoyable experience, especially for fans of the Harry Potter universe. It may not be perfect, but if you‚Äôve ever wanted to explore Hogwarts and live out your wizarding fantasy, this game is definitely worth playing.

Getting into it:

You don‚Äôt really get to be your own wizard in the game, you are the selfless hero or a mean spirited hero. Choosing the ‚Äúmeaner‚Äù option doesn‚Äôt impact your gameplay whatsoever and the main story along with many of the other character quests feel more like you are experiencing the story yourself rather than taking that much part in it. Yes you need to get things done to progress but when everything is laid out for you it's really not your story. As you get later into the game the story starts really lacking depth and the side quests get repetitive, I wish it was more of you trying to discover things on your own rather than the character telling you to do this so you have to do this or do something else to be able to then do this. There are some really interesting and fun parts of the story but a lot of duller moments that just feel like panning out the game as much as possible. - Unimaginative and bland characters
The game has two types of characters. The first type is cheerful, quirky and nice. The second type is brash, arrogant and evil. So far there is nothing else. This has frankly ruined my experience of the game as every character feels soulless and exactly the same.

Other issues:
- Uncanny valley voice acting
The voice acting on its own is actually quite good! However, there are some striking cases where the voice acting does not at all feel realistic given the character that's speaking and it destroys immersion every now and then. Examples are Arthur and Sirona.

- PC port and optimisation
This game does not feel like it was made for PC, especially when using keyboard and mouse. There are the usual issues with the camera and enemy targeting when using a mouse.

- Dialogue options
 Usually in games I love exploring the different dialogue options, but not this one. I rarely ever press a dialogue option and think "huh, I'm glad I decided to ask that", usually it's "Wow I wish that ended sooner". Not sure what it is.

- The combat, talents and spell slots

I think Skyrim's system with the different magic trees did a much better job.

Well, let's start by saying this game definitely has some interesting pros and quite a few cons.
Overall, as a game, it's pretty bad. During my playthrough, I encountered quite a few bugs, control issues, and camera glare.
I'll list some of the pros here first:
- The atmosphere of magic and Harry Potter is more than present here. Hogwarts Castle itself is quite large, intricate, and interesting to explore (in the beginning).
- There's also a good soundtrack, basically like in the film series.
- I liked the creatures featured here; at least we can interact with them and breed them.

Next comes the cons.
- TONS OF SIDE QUESTS!!! There are simply too many of them, there's absolutely no point in doing them, they don't give you anything, and the side quests themselves aren't particularly interesting. All the puzzles and other tasks scattered around the map are just a waste of your time. Don't do them. You don't have that inner worm in your head that tells you to complete the game 100%.
All the puzzles and "secrets" in Hogwarts are only interesting for the first couple of hours. Then you realize they're all the same old story and incredibly simple, and all interest simply vanishes.

- Performance issues. Even on my fairly good PC (4070, i7-13th gen), my FPS never rose above 60-70 and was mostly around 50. (If you don't care about achievements, you can use performance mods; fortunately, the developers decided to add official mods.)
There are also issues in locations. I often encountered camera flares that just shine in your face and you can't see anything, which was just infuriating. It's especially cool to get one during combat. Cool, excellent, awesome!

Speaking of combat, you'll just get pelted with meat. There are tons of enemies crawling out of every nook and cranny, and you seem to have defeated them all, BUT! A few more enemies have arrived. Most of these enemies are just punching bags that you simply click on, and after you click on a mob, your focus can say goodbye. Seriously, I had enough moments during battle when my character would automatically lock onto a defeated enemy or simply some object, and no matter what I did, my character wouldn't stop hitting it. I had to just run and dodge all enemy attacks while waiting for my camera control to return.

- Trials of Merlin and Alahamora. Pure torture. After completing the Trials of Merlin, I'm tempted to press skip to avoid watching the pre-recorded video, but unfortunately, there's no such option, so I have to watch the same thing over and over again.
The same goes for Alahamora; it's nonsense. Who the genius was who decided to add it as a minigame for hiding a castle is unclear. It would be fine if there weren't so many of them, but there are hundreds of them in the game, and you have to pick them, and every time you do, you look at it with a face like, "AGAIN?" It's unclear who the genius was who thought this would be cool, since it's just a waste of time that you can't skip if you want to complete all the content.

The game is also completely scripted. There are plenty of instances where a merchant starts telling you something, but the problem is, he's simply not there! He shouldn't be there according to the plot, but alas, the script demands a line from him. It's the same with enemies: some are covered in spiders and are effectively already dead, but the script demands a line from them.

There's nothing to say about the plot; it's just there. We'll ignore the fact that an ordinary schoolboy is destroying everyone and everything left and right, like a real Terminator, and the organization that was created to protect the magical world is always busy. You have goblins killing civilians‚Äîwe're busy. You have poachers chasing everyone ‚Äì we're busy. You have goblins staging a coup ‚Äì we're busy. It's the same with the constable in Hogsmeade: you hand him all the information on a silver platter, but the answer is ‚Äì don't bother.

The final battle, like the final mission, is extremely comical. Even Disney cartoons have more tension than that final scene; it's simply surreal.

Bottom line.
For all HP fans and regular players, my advice: Play only the story, complete a few side quests, explore the castle a bit, and as soon as you feel you're getting bored ‚Äì FORGET IT, it's not worth it.

While a very faithful painstaking recreation of both the school and world of harry potter, the fantasy is quite shaky. The music, world design, sound design, and voice acting is very evocative of scenes from the beloved movies but suffers in the aspects that make video games a really compelling medium.

Combat:
The combat is made to be easy to learn and quite casual, fun even, but ultimately shallow as it devolves into "match the enemy's shield color with your own colored spell." There are some enemies that have unique spell interactions such as plunging a certain spider's head into the soil with descendo (purple spell) when it rears into the air, the pick 4 cards spell systems makes uncovering these fun and rewarding interactions unlikely for the average player who may gravitate to 1 or 2 spell decks without swappping out spells too often after picking one they may end up partial to. This is how the colored spell system ends up hurting any semblance of depth with a large chunk of enemies. Purple and Yellow to break a shield and Red to hurt with "Green forbidden magic" to just be a debuff or instakill. If you play on the hardest difficulty then mages may now have a red shield. WOW! I think the card system holds back all the special effects from inffluencing better enemy design since attacks are easily parried or dodged with ample amounts of warning. Spells like expeliarmus being fantastic for mages is a good thing but you may opt to ignore that spell in your limited decks since a large chunk of enemies in the 40 hours i played, werent mages. You can have 4 decks of 4 cards but seeing as there are noncombat spells for creatures and the magical room you get to customize, realistically you will have 2 decks with the other 2 filled with the noncombat seplls for those respective parts of the game, limiting you to 8 spell slots for the pragmatic player that hates always going into the card menu to constantly swap around spells as they need. The card system ends up being a detriment to bot the cozy aspect of the game and the combat.

World and Characters:
Amazing level of detail on display but quite little put into characters that live in this world and even some seemingly silly additions to worldbuilding. You really only have 2 friends in this game, 1 boy from slytherin and 1 girl from gryffindor (as they have some narrative significance) and no real sense of attachment to any of your dorm mates as there aren't any real group activities outside of minor quests where you interact with their very one dimensional personalities, such as helping creatures or learning a spell. For a game set in a magical school, not having real friends is a terrible missed opportunity to liven up the "gallery" this game ends up being more often than not.
Here would be that example of that silly world building: The 1 friend from gryffindor comes from a school in Africa, where students dont use wands to which you can ask if that can be done without downside. The response is "yes, with no penalties, benefits, or differences from using a wand." If that were really true, wands wouldn't exist any longer. The narrative is a forgettable chosen one story that i couldn't be bothered to finish. Some activities for side content is fun and engaging but once you realize they usually result in a cosmetic item you won't particularly care for, you''l do them less frequently, most notably the merlin puzzles. The world is filled with quests that may interest you with the worldbuilding or oil down to a boring fetch quest to reward you with "better" gear item or an underwhelming cosmetic.

To elaborate on gear, it's mainly artificial number go up for the sake of level gating story quest and padding playtime with very little meaning for why this game even has a looting system. No buffing a specific spell or enhancing spell effects, just your take less dmg and deal more because arbitrary number is higher.

The devs probably fought hard to make this game so artistically faithful to the IP considering they worked under WB (and with all the harassment from Rowlings's online presence), but as far as a game in this genre goes, there are ones out there with a lot less bloat, more depth, less shallow characters, better narrative, and even more engaging combat. It's a very pretty look into the idea of a harry potter video game but that passion for recreating the world in a modern game comes at the cost of making a good game.

My PC is well beyond capable of maxing this game, yet I struggle for stable frames even on "minimum" settings. The optimization is ABYSMAL, HORRIBLE, and frankly embarrassing. The half-hour shader compilation every time you launch is a joke, only for the game to crash five minutes later. Unless the developers fix this mess, it will continue to suffer. 
Adding insult to injury, the gear and loot system is utterly useless; gear stats barely matter, making the endless cycle of collecting and managing inventory feel like meaningless busywork tacked onto an already tedious open world. Money system is awful and "punishes" the player. The core design of the game is stretched out to a groan-worthy extent. The linear plot is severely padded, leading to disastrous pacing. A fairly significant story progression is always accompanied by five useless, annoying fetch quests and filler missions, making the whole experience feel like a chore rather than a magical adventure. The game is far too long for what it offers, quickly becoming a slog. Furthermore, the characters are shallow, annoying, and instantly forgettable, carrying zero emotional weight, and the voice acting is maddening. The world is riddled with buggy collectibles and an excessive number of puzzles that eventually make you loathe the sight of any locked door.

Despite these massive cons, among others I won't go on about, the game is genuinely good at its core. When it works, the combat is pretty fun and fluid. Fighting with powerful magic, chaining huge combos, and deploying massive abilities feels great. The enemy/mob and world design(s) are fantastic, and the overall graphics are good, even when suffering performance issues. There is tons of cool stuff to do, from flying on a broom and fighting goblins to designing your workshop-room. It's a fun experience that doesn't actually require any prior Harry Potter knowledge. However, the developers make you fight harder against the optimization than against any in-game boss. As it stands, it‚Äôs fun, but barely playable.

On a massive sale it's not a bad buy, but keep all of this in mind. As it sits I can't give it more than a 5.5/10 with a clear conscience. If at least the crashing/performance issues are ever fixed, I'd rate it at as a potential 7.5/10, but until then it's a mid experience overall.
